title: 112_hr3766
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jeremy Bell Act of 2011" and pertains to an offense. The "Jeremy Bell Act of 2011" prohibits the interstate transfer of child sex offenders for employment purposes. Employers who facilitate the travel of an employee engaged in sexual conduct with a minor across state lines can face fines or imprisonment. The "Jeremy Bell Act of 2011" prohibits interstate transfer of child sex offenders for employment if the conduct is a sexual act, occurred during employment, and would be a felony violation. The term 'State' includes the District of Columbia and other US territories. SEC. 9537 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 requires schools to conduct background checks on all employees. SEC. 9537 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 mandates that schools must ensure all employees undergo fingerprint-based national and state criminal history checks to receive funding. SEC. 9538. STATE LAW. Amendment to ESEA to include background checks on all employees. State law requires reporting of sexual conduct involving a minor at schools, with penalties for non-compliance and sharing of offender information. State law mandates reporting incidents of sexual conduct with a minor at schools, leading to termination of employment for offenders. Safeguards are in place to restrict access to this information to educational agencies only. The Secretary will establish regulations for states to follow in implementing these requirements and reporting terminated employment of offenders to schools. The term 'minor' refers to an individual under 18 years of age, and 'school' is defined as a public or private entity that provides education to students with support from educational programs. The term 'sexual conduct' is defined in section 1822 of title 18, United States Code. The table of contents in the Act is amended to include this definition. State law.
